author: potuz
content: Hello, can anyone point me to an existing blockchain/rollup/sidechain/L2 worth more than zero, relying on KZG commitments?

author: kevaundray
content: Aztec network (zkRollup) uses the KZG polynomial commitment scheme and is worth more than 0. A link to code can be seen here: <https://github.com/AztecProtocol/barretenberg/blob/master/barretenberg/src/aztec/plonk/proof_system/verifier/verifier.cpp#L118>

author: kevaundray
content: It uses _standard_ techniques to open multiple polynomials which are evaluated at the same point with a single witness and verify multiple proofs in batch. The techniques should be noted in the PLONK paper

author: potuz
content: Thanks a lot, more than code itself I worry about the plausibility of testing/validating the specs here. Besides a handfull of EF guys writing and reviewing Dankrad's PR, and a couple of Stanford and Oxford postdocs that are active in ethresear.ch, how many people within the community have actual deep knowledge of the mathematics involved? We can be told that no mathematical knowledge is needed to vet the specs, but to vet this statement in itself requires deep mathematical knowledge of the system

author: protolambda
content: https://dankradfeist.de/ethereum/2020/06/16/kate-polynomial-commitments.html is a great resource to learn about KZG

author: kevaundray
content: Oh I see, is it not possible to use the commitment scheme as a black box and delegate the validating of that part to others, or at least a partial black box? Partial in the sense that you at least trust that pairings work as expected

author: kevaundray
content: I don't have specific context here, but I'm assuming that at some point, one will need to draw an abstraction over how the cryptography works

author: potuz
content: I understand this, my question is actually quite basic: The way I've been learning about governance at least in the CL of ethereum so far it has worked along the following lines after the R&D stage is done (where a lot of work is put). Someone typically from the EF or from one of the client teams puts out a PR with the implementation. It goes through vetting mostly by people of the EF R&D in the first rounds, and mostly by client devs in the last rounds when edge cases or performance issues are found. Everything gets merged when Danny gives the OK. My problem with  this particular PR is how many people can actually review it. I expect almost zero people in client teams to have deep knowledge of the math involved (they shouldn't need this) and taking it as a blackbox does work to vet part of it, but not to try to imagine attack vectors. In regards to <@!427491045308235776> 's comment: I am fine abstracting away EC cryptography that has been battle tested everywhere for over 30 years. I am not happy at all that KZG's paper is from 2010 only with less than 100 citations. At the very least you should grant me that it's a very different situation

author: kevaundray
content:
Oh I see your concern, yeah I agree that its a different situation than if we were abstracting away EC cryptography, RSA or sha256 for example. 

In those cases, they have a lot _more_ cryptanalysis and _usually_ have some sort of standard that makes it harder to repeat mistakes that past cryptographers have made.  Not to say that pairings for example, have not received any/sufficient attention as I cannot judge. Just that the amount is vastly different at this moment in time, compared to much older cryptography

author: kevaundray
content:
In regards to citations, I think it might be fairer to count how many citations pairing based commitment schemes or pairing schemes in general have gotten in this particular context, as I think this is the "new" thing compared to using something like a pedersen based commitment scheme for example which only relies on the discrete logarithm problem.

Groth16 for example has over 400 citations according to eprint

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: An interesting experience in this departament - last semester I decided to give my students to implement KZG10 and related things for data sharding ( https://github.com/sifraitech/kzg ) Each team did a port of c-kzg/go-kzg to Rust using different BLS libraries. Last week we had an exam. While they did a pretty good coding with tests/benchmarks (MCL is the fastest) I must say no one really understood how KZG10 actually works even though I spent multiple hours explaining it in informal ways. And this scheme is relatively easy to understand (except pairings).

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: So my conclusion is that you should not expect regular blockchain engineer to understand the underlying cryptography. But they should use a ready-to-use crypto libraries correctly. The underlying cryptography is a hard thing (take any modern scheme like Plonk) and thatâ€™s something a great cryptography engineer understands, and only a few teams has one.
